11:25 am

Here's Olivetree

BE11:26am

Sophos is currently part owned by Apax, it acquired a majority stake in 2010 and has been selling down since (IPO in 2015), with 10.15% currently. This has also irrevocably pledged to accept the proposal and does not relaease in the event of a higher proposal from elsewhere. Given it is so clean, impediments to the transaction completing look small – it is envisaged that it will complete in Q1 2020. The combination of valuation / low conditionality and irrevocable structure make it feel like a stock which will trade close to the proposed takeout terms for the life of the transaction. All eyes will be on whether there is any scope for a strategic competitor to try to compete for the asset but this seems a low probability – presumably Apax and co-founders Lammer & Hruska know where the bodies lie in this regard.

rw42 @izzy cynic available on demand, to point out the problems any solutions will cause :)
PBateman Struck gold with Soph! Bought on warning and +62%.. chump change but still
BE11:26am

Looking at Bloomberg data on precedent deals for Infrastructure Software and Equipment on listed companies. Granted this is not a big sample but millennia median takeout multiples are 21.7x EBITDA 27.75x EBIT and 31.5x PE. Running that over Sophos numbers it looks like they agreed a transaction in line with precedent deals on 2021 numbers and at uplift of 2020 numbers, so it is hard to argue with the price on offer here.

PBateman Something to be said for buying quality on a dip/warning

#REF! re Olivetree grey: EBITDA and PEnot great for Sophos given pre_payments and odd WC. FCF multiple makes more sense
BE11:27am

Given the share price reaction we move to Hold. Here is the news. . . Operating results are on an improving trend, H1 billings zoom past our H1 expectations, forecasts are suppressed (well given the heartache, what do you expect?), the CFO has resigned, shareholders have been grumbling (note voting at the AGM), and of course STG£ is in the can. This can only be a great time for a smart buyer to step in. Step forward Thoma Bravo. We are delighted with the recommended cash offer to be made by Bidco (Thoma Bravo) for Sophos by way of a scheme of arrangement. The Sophos Shareholder receives US $7.40/share cash – c.583p – a 37.1% to the undisturbed price 425.5p on the last Business Day before the announcement. The Acquisition values Sophos at c.US$3,820m on a fully diluted basis and implies an EV US$3,948m. The valuation is c.32x Sophos' unlevered free cash flow of US$124m (FY ended 31 March 2019), c.5.3x EV/Sales, 37x EV/EBITDA. Irrevocables are 27% - but this start point would be par for the course. Remember: (i) the CFO has already resigned, (ii) this was a June 2015 IPO at 225p, so shareholders have done well, but it has been a rocky journey, (iii) we met the company at a trade event on Thursday last and we fell in love with the products and opportunity – best of breed,, managed services, synchronized security – Sophos ticks all the boxes, in our view. We are not convinced of a competing bid, but urge investors to hold off for now. We move our rating to Hold with a target price of 583p.

BE11:30am

Morgan Stanley:

11:30 am
BE11:30am

At 583p Sophos would trade at c. 25x EV/FCFF, this compares to US peers Palo Alto at 17.5x, Fortinet at 15x and Checkpoint at 13.5x (2020e EV/FCFF). The scale of the premium to Friday's close as well as US peers, could present a challenge to any potential counter bid. We also note Sophos has this morning issued a trading update indicating it expects to deliver c. 9% organic billings growth for 1H20, in-line with MSe and c. 1-2% ahead of street expectations, the second quarter in row of high single digit growth. We note continued M&A activity in the sector with US based Symantec (covered by Keith Weiss) recently selling its Enterprise security division to Broadcom (covered by Craig Hettenbach) for 4.5x EV/Sales and it has reportedly also received PE interest from Advent and Permira (WSJ, September 6) for the remaining consumer piece - none of the companies have commented. We remain Overweight Avast (410p PT) which is also operating in the security software space, albeit more focused on the consumer side, Equal-weight Software AG trading at c. 3.6x NTM EV/Recurring, and Underweight Sage trading at 21x CY20e P/E.

FATDAZ @Praxis saw a headline this morning suggesting Softbank were trying to take control of the business as cash resources were getting strained didnt read body of the piece ..... but you have to ask yourself if it was that strapped for cash why it was suitable to float / IPO and what disclosures about cash flow where in prospectus
BE11:32am

Neil Campling had an early doors note though, I think. Mirabaud.

PBateman Any thoughts as to why the soph bid isn't fixed in GBP?
11:33 am
BE11:33am

By way of background Thoma Bravo acquired Barracuda, Sophos’s closest comp, last year and this year alone has made 12 acquisitions in total. Thoma Bravo already has 13 flagship funds and a report just last week suggested the firm could begin a $15B fundraising for a 14th fund in the first half of 2020. The company last week announced a deal for IDS, a specialised asset finance software company and closed a $3.7B deal of mortgage software provider Ellie Mae in April. Their cyber security portfolio has been involved in Sailpoint (2017 exit), McAfee, SonicWall (exit 2012), Blue Coat (exit 2013), Tripwire (exit 2015) and Idaptive.

Last quarter, Sophos posted 7% CC revenue growth, 9% billings growth and 10% subscription growth. The update for the H2 is 9% CC billings growth, 12% subscription billings growth. The 118% renewal rate in Q1 was a 300bps improvement YoY with potential for sequential acceleration through the year (which was the trend which played out in FY20). Sophos is expected to see a sequential improvement QoQ in billings through FY20, supported by new product releases (and this has played out in Q1 and Q2). Sophos ‘burnt’ investors during a tough FY19 and has had a mixed success in execution. Barracuda had gone through a similar volatile billings growth profile before being acquired by Thoma Bravo. That company was acquired just at a time the core billings began to improve, new products had been released and renewal rates improved. A similar e company was and is likely still in the penalty box and needs to show that Q1 FY20 wasn’t a one off improvement. But given the stock is -25% over a year, easy comps and improving billings metrics this one is worthy of further exploration.

Thoma Bravo strategy is focused on free cash flow. Sophos could be valuably merged with Barrcuda to focus on the SMB opportunities. Another acquisition by Thoma Bravo in the space is Impeva, completed in January which had a leading position in the WAF (web application firewall) market and a SecureSphere platform for on premise security platform.

BE11:39am

Boris Johnson’s hopes of sealing a Brexit deal in time for a critical EU summit later this week were in jeopardy on Sunday evening after two days of intensive negotiations left Brussels baffled about the UK’s new customs proposals.

Michel Barnier, EU chief Brexit negotiator, told diplomats on Sunday evening that British plans to keep Northern Ireland in the UK’s customs territory while avoiding a hard border on the island of Ireland were fiendishly complex and not yet properly worked out. 

There was “no breakthrough yet”, said one EU diplomat, while noting it was positive that talks would continue in Brussels on Monday. “If the British government wants a solution, it must move quickly now. The clock is ticking.”

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Brexit negotiating teams from the UK and the EU are now embarking on intensive, technical discussions in preparation for the European Council meeting on 17-18 October. The decision to intensify talks follows a bilateral meeting between UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, after which both leaders agreed that “a pathway to a possible deal” had emerged. We maintain our base case that the UK will leave the EU by 31 October with a close variant of the Withdrawal Agreement negotiated under former Prime Minister Theresa May.
The government has called a sitting of Parliament for 19th October; only the second time, since the Falklands War in 1982, that Parliament has sat on a Saturday. The timing of this is crucial because the 19th is also the deadline for a deal to be passed in the UK Parliament, otherwise the Prime Minister will need to officially ask the EU-27 for another Brexit extension.

Upaswellasdown @Fatdaz - well yes, though I was thinking more in terms of actual real operating differences. Acquire more?
PBateman I had avast free and when they properly monetized it, it was shocking
BE11:42am

In our view, a mutually acceptable compromise is likely to be struck around the New Customs Partnership originally envisaged in the Brexit deal negotiated under former Prime Minister Theresa May. In a revamp of the backstop proposed under that deal, Northern Ireland would effectively sit in the customs territories of both the United Kingdom and the European Union, albeit subject to the cross-community consent of the Northern Ireland Assembly. In this configuration, no customs or regulatory checks would be required on the island of Ireland, and the UK would be able to negotiate free-trade agreements with its partners around the world. In effect, a Northern-Ireland-specific solution of this kind would meet the same objectives of the original UK-wide customs backstop, albeit via different legal and administrative mechanisms. The legal and technical difficulties associated with this proposal should not be dismissed, but our reading of the politics points in this direction.
Will a deal finally get through UK Parliament? We think it would as the interest of three crucial groups are becoming aligned. In our central scenario, the DUP are ultimately satisfied that the Good Friday Agreement has been preserved and Northern Ireland’s place in the United Kingdom has been protected. Conditional on DUP support, we think Conservative Eurosceptics will be satisfied that the new Withdrawal Agreement does not preclude a future UK-EU free-trade agreement that leaves scope for a significant degree of regulatory divergence. In addition, we think there are 20-30 Labour MPs from “Leave” constituencies who would be willing to defy the Labour whip in order to secure an orderly Brexit before the next general election. In our view, the incentive for those Opposition rebels to support a Brexit deal are likely to be strengthened by an attempt by pro-EU backbenchers to attach a confirmatory second referendum to any deal that PM Johnson brings back from Brussels.

BE11:54am

Elizabeth Warren’s comments to “ban fracking everywhere” drew a lot of attention and raised concerns for those invested and active in the industry. Ms. Warren would be able to issue this executive action without approval from Congress.
Our conversations with experts indicate that a frac ban would most likely be limited to federal lands (12% of all active permits) and to expect industry to pursue legal recourse including an injunction until courts make a final decision on that action.

BE11:54am

A federal land drilling ban in early 2021 would reduce our US oil production growth by 300 Mb/d that year and our 2025 forecast by 1.2 MMb/d. Natural gas growth would be trimmed by 4 Bcf/d.
 We think the supply reduction would increase global oil prices by $5-10/bbl over the following years resulting in an increase to gasoline prices by $0.10-0.25/gal.
 Federal oil & gas revenue would likely drop by $15-20 billion over the next five years.

BE11:55am

How Bad Would a Frac Ban be for Companies with Federal Acreage?
 Most companies we analyzed have ample state/fee acreage but the market could overreact, which may provide fundamental buying opportunities. The value opportunity on federal acreage could be preserved during future changes in the White House.
 If a federal land frac ban occurred…within the Energy Sector for investor positioning, we think Canada Integrateds would be most attractive while US E&P would be most at risk.
Companies with larger federal acreage exposure would likely be most at risk to other basins and larger relative state/fee land positions

BE12:03pm

Ocado shares had a strong run in the last 12m with the company
having announced several deals with supermarket players around the
globe to run their online solutions. In this note, we revisit the investment
case and provide a deep dive into the company's revenue model and –
more importantly – its cash flow streams going forward. We conclude that
Ocado’s current valuation at £9bn is already stretched – the Retail JV with
Marks & Spencer (M&S) together with the Solutions projects already
committed are worth £3.9bn combined, reflecting just ~40% of current
market cap. The remaining value is ascribed to potential new signings (i.e.
more clients/more CFCs with existing clients) and suggests at least
additional 126 CFCs will be contracted – versus 38 announced so far (incl.
20 for Kroger alone) and only 3 operational as of today. This may happen
but at this point we do not see risk/reward as compelling and scope for
outperformance appears limited. We downgrade the shares from N to UW;
our DCF-based Dec 2020 PT of 1050p now offers -19% downside.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

The final quarter looks problematic for most of our industrial coverage given weak manufacturing lead indicators, trade tariffs and Sterling volatility around Brexit. As such, we cut our FY19/20E earnings estimates for several mechanical and electrical engineers by up to 9%. Nevertheless, pockets of value have emerged and we upgrade Smiths to Buy (from Hold) given attractive late cycle exposure and the impending Medical demerger. It may be too early to call the trough in early-cycle stocks that rolled over last autumn, but it is nearer. Melrose (Buy) has the most self-help potential, and the GKN improvement is on track. We also highlight Morgan Advanced, Ultra Electronics and Chemring, where the medicine from relatively new management teams is working. Within Aerospace & Defence, we upgrade QinetiQ to Buy (from Hold) and Rolls Royce to Hold (from Sell) but move Meggitt to Hold (from Buy). Outbound Cobham is downgraded to Hold (from Buy) simply as the shares trade near the Advent bid price. Defence spending is increasing while civil aircraft orders have rolled over. Our target prices have increased for most of the Defence names, been reduced for Senior (Hold) and estimates for Avon Rubber (Hold) have been updated for its recent acquisition. Over the past twelve months, being long defence and short early-cycle industrial exposure would have outperformed. There was investor resistance to Defence at this time last year, and we are having similar conversations on the late-cycle Oilfield Services names today, on which we are positive. We also argue that there is value within the Paper & Packaging stocks
